 1. THE ENERGY SECTOR A. OVERVIEW 1.1 The consumption of energy and electricity in Thailand has grown at high rates over the past decade and particularly since 1986 due to the strong economic performance of the country, arising from rapid industrial growth, and increases in exports, foreign investment and tourism. In spite of this rapid growth, however, the energy situation in Thailand remains characterized by relatively modest commercial energy consumption in relation to the country's development (320 kilograms of oil equivalent (koe) consumption of energy per capita compared with an average of 420 koe per capita for all of Asia). This includes a relatively high share (35%) of traditional fuels in the final energy consumption. The primary commercial energy supply is projected to grow at an average annual rate of about 8.0% over the next four years (1997-2000) and then at about 5.7% for the next decade. 1.2 While much of the energy growth in the early 1980s was met by imports, efforts in the 1980s to promote the development of indigenous energy resources had a visible impact on the pattem of commercial energy consumption: the share of oil fell from about 90% of total primary commercial energy in 1980 to about 70% in 1990. During that period, the shares of indigenous lignite and natural gas grew steadily, reaching 10% and 16%, respectively, by 1990. Due to Govermment's continuing efforts, the share of imported oil is anticipated to fall further to about 60% by the year 2005; it is, however, unlikely to decline below that level. A major increase in the consumption of imported coal (mostly for power generation) is projected in the late 1990s, and coal is expected to attain a share of 8% of primary energy consumption after the year 2001. 1.3 The sectoral composition of energy demand has been marked by a progressive increase in the share of the transport sector, which grew 11% p.a. through the 1980s and by 1990 accounted for 70% of petroleum products consumption. Electricity consumption has increased faster than energy consumption as a whole, averaging 14% p.a. in the last three years. As a result, the share of electricity in final commercial energy consumption grew from 11% to 15% in the 1980s, with a similar increase in the share of electricity in primary energy use from 7% to 11%. B. ENERGY SECTOR INSTITUTIONS 1.4 The energy sector in Thailand is operated by a number of well-managed and mature public institutions. There are numerous energy-related agencies, spreading across many ministries and include several cabinet level committees. Energy policy and planning is vested in key govemmental organizations. At the highest level is the National Energy Policy Council (NEPC) which is chaired by the Prime Minister. The National Energy Policy Office (NEPO), the secretariat to NEPC, acts as its operating arm, and functions primarily as a link between NEPC and the country's energy state enterprises and conducts all energy policy work. NEPO is the de facto regulator of the energy sector. Other departments involved in energy affairs are: (a) the Department of Mineral Resources, responsible for assessing and preliminary exploration of the country's coal and petroleum reserves; (b) the Department of Energy Development and Promotion, which conducts research and development and monitors energy sector activities; and
 2 (c) the Department of Industrial Works, responsible for controlling industrial air and water pollution. 1.5 Energy state enterprises enjoy a large degree of autonomy in the conduct of day-to-day operations; however, they are subject to strict government control in all matters relating to investment planning and financing. Because of strict procedures for controlling public debt, all loans made by energy state enterprises requiring government guarantees must be approved by the National Debt Policy Committee and the Cabinet. While many of these enterprises still lack financial discipline and autonomy or suffer from cumbersome personnel policies, they are now in the process of undergoing a major restructuring of their organizations through corporatization, with a view to privatization. 1.6 The Petroleum Authority of Thailand (PTT)-the dominant entity in the petroleum sector-is involved in downstream oil and gas activities; upstream activities are carried out by the private sector. PTT is responsible, inter alia, for the purchase, transport, processing and sale of natural gas. However, PTT competes with international oil companies and has a third of the market share in the distribution and marketing of oil. 1.7 The power sector is primarily organized around three wholly-owned state enterprises. The Electricity Generating Authority of Thailand (EGAT) is the major producer of electricity and is also responsible for developing and dispatching the bulk-power high voltage transmission system. EGAT has the authority to purchase electricity from co-generators or other private sources for distribution over the grid. The Metropolitan Electricity Authority (MEA) and the Provincial Electricity Authority (PEA) own the distribution systems and some subtransmission facilities. MEA and PEA distribute electricity purchased from EGAT to the Bangkok metropolitan area and the rest of the country, respectively. Highlights of their respective operation are provided in Annex 1. C. THE POWER SECTOR Electricity Demand 1.8 The power sector in Thailand has grown at a rapid pace over the past two decades. The electricity market growth is among the highest in the world and has been fueled by the country's high economic growth rate. Considerable progress has been made in making electricity widely available, especially in provincial urban areas. Industrial consumption has also been growing rapidly. 1.9 The latest demand forecast made by the national Load Forecast Subcommittee (composed inter alia of NEPO, EGAT, MEA and PEA) takes into consideration the recent slowing down of the economy and envisages continued but moderate load growth rates commensurate with the expected economic performance. Base case demand growth rates for EGAT, MEA (Annex 2) and PEA for the Seventh (1992-1996), Eighth (1997-2001) and Ninth Plan (2002-2006) periods are summarized in Table 1.1. These growth rates are considered to be reasonable and achievable. In 1994, Thailand electricity demand was 10,709 MW. The demand is forecast to increase to

System Losses and Reliability 1.10 Total losses in the system were approximately 7.7% of total power generated in 1995, down from the 1994 level of 8.6%. The level has fallen in recent years as problems with power line upgrades have been resolved. About 3.2% of electricity generated has been lost in transmission lines and transformers in 1995, better than the 1994 level of 4.1%. Distribution losses as a percentage of power received were about 4.5% for MEA and 6% for PEA, an achievement by both organizations which ranks with the best performing power utilities in Asia. With the ever increasing demands placed on the distribution networks of both PEA and MEA, the reliability of both these networks have been deteriorating substantially over the last few years. Under the guidance of a "Reliability Committee" chaired by NEPO, several comprehensive reliability studies have been undertaken by consultants. Implementation of the recommendations of these studies, feature in the Eighth Plan investments of both MEA and PEA. Agreement was reached at negotiations that MEA would contain its system losses at current levels (not to exceed 5%), and in consultation with the Bank, take any additional measures that would be called for to meet this requirement. Thailand's Power Development Plan 1.11 Meeting increased load demand and improving the electricity transmission and distribution systems will require considerable investment, estimated at about B 429 billion under the Eighth Plan. For a long-term profile up to the year 2011, the Power Development Plan (PDP) recommends the installation of 33,676 MW of new generating capacity, net of the retirement of 2,747 MW of existing power plants. By September 2011, the sector's total capacity will be 43,918 MW comprising of 11% hydro, 25% conventional oil/gas fired, 7% lignite-fired, 11% imported coal-fired, 10% combined cycle, 8% gas turbine, and 28% from independent power producers (IPPs). POWER SECTOR REFORM 1.13 Power sector reform in Thailand began in 1992 with the issuance of the seventh National Economic and Social Development Plan (NESDP). The seventh NESDP which covers the period 1992-96, led to the development of a Cabinet resolution for power sector reform providing indicative targets for restructuring, corporatization and privatization in the power sector. The main objectives of this resolution are to: (a) reduce the investment and debt burden of the Government; (b) promote private sector participation in the power sector through IPPs; (c) encourage the operation of power utilities as commercial organizations with increased efficiency and flexibility; and (d) utilize energy resources efficiently. Progress towards achieving all these objectives over the last four years has been substantive. Despite the slippage of some targets in a few instances, many of the reform goals specified in this seventh NESDP have been achieved or are in advanced stages of implementation. Commitment to continued reform is also clearly in evidence. 1.14 The Bank's operational involvement in the Thai power sector has continuously provided inputs to the country's power sector reform process. Government strategy and implementation have been in conformance with Bank policies and the recommendations for the sector as detailed in the Bank's study-"State Enterprise: Improvement, Privatization and Private Sector
 5 Participation" (Report No. 1312-TH). The main elements of the reform strategy and future implementation issues discussed below indicate the success of the Thai power reform effort in meeting stated objectives. Sector Restructuring (a) In February 1996, NEPO submitted and obtained approval by the Cabinet for a medium-term structure for the Electricity Supply Industry. This structure shown in Annex 3 propounds the formation of a central purchasing agency, a business unit comprising the EGAT transmission system and hydro power plants. The thermal plants under EGAT will be converted to three independent business units by end-1997 and will sell power to EGAT's transmission business unit on the basis of transparent power sales contracts. The generation business units are proposed to be subsequently corporatized and privatized. (b) All sales of bulk electricity from EGAT (transmission company) to the distribution companies PEA and MEA will be based on an efficient bulk supply tariff (BST). The existing bulk tariff has in-built cross-subsidies as the tariff policy has required that retail electricity sales by MIEA and PEA be priced uniformly throughout the country. EGAT's differential tariffs to MEA and PEA have been the vehicle of subsidization for the rural areas. It has been the Government's intention to eliminate the cross subsidy from EGAT's tariffs. A Study on the Rationalization of Bulk Supply Tariff to MEA and PEA was undertaken with Bank financing under the Lam Takhong Pump Storage Project (Loan 3884-TH). The study provides the basis for a more efficient BST structure and a means for regulating the power sector entities. NEPO expects the revised bulk tariff structure to be introduced by end- 1997. Enterprise Reform 1.15 As part of a broader strategy of public enterprise reform in Thailand, the power sector enterprises are being restructured to operate more like commercial enterprises. A strategy of phased commercialization and corporatization is being followed. The objective is eventual privatization. EGAT, MEA and PEA are each at different stages in this process. (a) The Government has established performance targets for enterprises in different sectors that allow them to be classified as an excellent state enterprise. In the case of the power sector, classification as an excellent state enterprise status requires: (a) return on revalued assets greater than 6%; (b) labor cost below 20% of total costs; and (c) annual productivity increases equal to or greater than 2%. Achievement of the excellent state enterprise status provides management with the authority to devise and implement a suitable staffing and compensation system. EGAT achieved excellent state enterprise status in 1995. This step has had a major impact in improving management incentives and is crucial to achieving a smooth transition to a commercial operating status. Both PEA and MEA expect to achieve this status in 1997.
 6 (b) Following an independent "audit" of EGAT under the Second Power System Development Project (Loan 3138-TH), EGAT obtained government approval for its organizational restructuring plans in February 1996. These plans are now being implemented. EGAT has created six business units (i.e. profit centers), and five operating units (i.e. cost centers). The business units are: thermal generation; transmission; engineering; construction; mining and maintenance. The operating units are: governor's office and internal audit; hydro power plants; administration; accounting and finance; policy and planning and new business ventures. Asset restructuring for the creation of profit centers is in progress. All transactions between business units will be conducted on the basis of transparent transfer prices. Once this structure is developed on a sound commercial footing, the business units will be corporatized and then could either be wholly- or partially- privatized. The progress on privatization will depend on the absorptive capacity of domestic capital markets. (c) Following the preparation of a PEA Privatization Implementation Program under the Distribution System Reinforcement Project (Loan 3138-TH), PEA prepared a corporate restructuring action plan. The PEA action plan has been approved by the Cabinet and is currently under implementation under the Distribution Automation and Reliability Improvement Project (Loan 4067-TH). PEA will be transformed over a 4-5 year period from a centrally controlled government agency, to regionally decentralized corporate subsidiaries under a holding company structure. Following an "audit" of MEA's institution under the Distribution System and Energy Efficiency Project (Loan 3598-TH), MEA has recently prepared an organizational restructuring plan in consultation with the Bank and this plan is acceptable to NEPO. It is expected that MEA would follow a phased reorganization strategy, first becoming a state holding company with separate subsidiaries and profit centers. The separation of "supply" and "distribution" would be a major step forward in the separation of distribution accounts and for wholesale choice by large consumers. Power Sector Regulation (a) In June 1996, the Cabinet agreed on two key principles for regulatory reform in the power sector. First, the concept of independent regulation for the sector has been accepted. This will begin with the separation of the policy and regulatory functions of NEPO and the creation of a separate unit with regulatory responsibility. Second, the basis for tariff regulation will ensure that power sector enterprises meet a minimum self-financing ratio (SFR) of 25%. SFR would be the governing financial covenant for regulation in lieu of a rate-of-return on assets. A large part of this work was completed under the study on the Rationalization of Bulk Supply Tariff undertaken with Bank financing under the Lam Takhong Pump Storage Project (Loan 3884-TH). The detailed sector regulation principles concerning investment, tariffs, and service standards will be defined under a subsequent study on Regulation in the Energy Sector being initiated under the Distribution Automation and Reliability Improvement Project (Loan 4067-TH).
 7 (b) The regulatory principles developed by NEPO have been submitted for Cabinet review and approval. In parallel, NEPO has also issued draft service performance standards to the power enterprises (i.e. EGAT, MEA and PEA). The power enterprises have begun to develop and revise their long-term investment plans and prepare financial projections to meet these service standards. Discussions on these financial projections and service standards will continue between the utilities and NEPO. It is expected that the performance standards and financial projections will be agreed upon by end- 1997, whereafter formal regulatory supervision will commence. Private Sector Participation (a) Asset Divestiture: In 1992, EGAT established EGCO as its subsidiary company with an issued share capital of Baht 100 million divided into 10 million shares of Baht 10 each. On September 30, 1993, EGAT held the entire equity with the exception of 15 shares which were issued to EGAT senior management to comply with the Stock Exchange of Thailand (SET) regulations. In 1994, a further 186 million shares of Baht 10 each were issued, all of which are held by EGAT except for one million held by the Thai Property Crown Bureau and which increased EGAT's total holding to almost 192 million shares. In addition to the flotation of additional shares by EGCO during the year, it also set up its own subsidiary, the Rayong Electricity Generating Company (REGCO). In November 1994, a public offering of 204 million shares in EGCO raised Baht 4.5 billion. Presently, 58% of EGCO is publicly listed, EGAT holds 41% of the equity and the Property Crown Bureau the remaining 1%. (b) Small Power Producers (SPPs) and Co-Generation: The first step taken by the Government towards increasing private sector participation was allowing co- generators and SPPs to sell power to EGAT. In 1994, a co-generation agreement was signed with a private company to bring on line a new 60 MW facility. Currently, there are 20 SPPs with a total installed capacity of 669 MW mostly utilizing traditional fuels such as bagasse, rice husk, wood, etc. (c) Independent Power Producers (IPPs): To meet the ever increasing power requirements, Thailand launched the world's largest competitive IPP solicitation program. EGAT announced the first request for proposals on December 15, 1994 to purchase 5,000 MW from IPPs to the year 2002. As of December 1996, 104 registered IPPs/bidders have formed into 32 consortia and have submitted 50 IPP proposals totaling 39,067 MW. Contracts are currently being finalized with about seven developers. E. DEMAND-SIDE MANAGEMENT AND ELECTRICITY CONSERVATION 1.16 While pursuing a large power development program, the Govemment has planned a thrust towards energy conservation. The Bank has played a pioneering role in the development of
 8 Thailand's demand-side management (DSM) program, supported by the Global Environmental Facility (GEF) under the Distribution System and Energy Efficiency Project (Loan 3598-TH). This program has a four-pronged approach: (a) provision of user and manufacturer incentives and consumer education to direct practices and attitudes toward energy efficient technologies; (b) development of efficiency standards and testing capabilities to exercise control and monitor efficiency improvements; (c) development and promulgation of building and appliance codes to allow for the enforcement of minimum standards; and (d) continued pursuit of technological improvements and adaptation to Thai conditions. This program is progressing very well and is recognized as the most comprehensive program of its kind in East Asia. The current demand savings target of about 1,100 MW over the next five years, substantially exceeds the original target of about 300 MW. However, the DSM program is currently being exclusively managed by EGAT, MEA having no expertise in this field. Introducing DSM capabilities in MEA, deepening the DSM focus to Thailand's most rapidly growing area, is planned under the proposed project (para. 3.4). F. ENVIRONMTENT 1.17 In the last few years, the Government has placed a strong emphasis on environmentally sound and sustainable development. Its 1992 Energy Conservation Promotion Act, created an Energy Conservation Fund, financed by surcharges on petroleum products and electricity. The Act provides for a rigorous enforcement of energy conservation in factories and buildings. The Environmental Quality Act of 1992: (a) substantially reorganized the environmental bureaucracy making it more responsive to environmental protection needs; (b) established a Central Environmental Fund for concessional financing of environmental projects by the private and public sectors; and (c) recognized for the first time the importance of involving Non- Governmental Organizations (NGOs) in development. Gaining from its experience under the Third Power System Development Project (Loan 3423-TH), the Government has increasingly emphasized involvement of affected people and selected NGOs in environmentally sensitive projects and formalized this in the evaluation of Environmental Impact Assessments (EIAs). G. BANK LENDING FOR THE SECTOR Experience with Past Loans 1.18 The Bank has made 25 loans to Thailand for power, of which 18 have been made to EGAT, six to PEA and one to MEA. Of the 18 loans to EGAT, 17 have been fully disbursed and the only on-going project is the Lam Takhong Pump Storage Project (Loan 3884-TH, signed on September 8, 1995). Three of the loans to PEA have been fully disbursed; while the rest are under supervision. The overall progress in the implementation of MEA's Distribution System and Energy Efficiency Project (Loan 3598-TH) is satisfactory and about 90% of the work is now completed. Under this loan, two studies were completed: (a) an "audit" of MEA's institution which helped identify the entity's weaknesses and strengths and will underpin MEA's organizational restructuring under the proposed project; and (b) Safety and Environmental
 9 Considerations in System Design-whose recommendations are already under implementation by MEA. 1.19 The design and procurement delays experienced in the earlier stages of MEA's project have emphasized the need for: (a) early procurement of land for substations; and (b) advance preparation of bid documents. The proposed project addresses these issues through: (a) sufficiently advanced action having been taken by MEA in securing land for the substations (all land is already available); and (b) issuing of the first lot of bid documents. Rationale for Bank Involvement 1.20 Among the priority areas for Bank assistance identified in the Country Assistance Strategy discussed by the Board on September 24, 1994, the development of physical infrastructure and improvement in environmental management rank very high. These are also the priorities of the Government and it has frequently reiterated the importance of Bank involvement and the weight it attached to the Bank's technical assistance and operational support. Along with a modest level of borrowing, the Government is keen to continue this involvement so as to elaborate and implement strategies that have been launched with assistance from the Bank. The Bank's operational involvement will help assure that the momentum of reform is maintained and the sector evolves in an economically efficient, financially sound and environmentally sustainable manner. Already, during the preparation of the proposed project, the Bank has been instrumental in: (a) MEA developing a plan for restructuring its organization in a manner that has been accepted by NEPO; and (b) encouraging MEA to proceed with DSM related work. Under the proposed project the Bank would be assisting MEA in its efforts towards commercialization and corporatization as well as becoming an important player in DSM, in spite of having no past experience in this area.

 2. THE BORROWER 2.1 The Metropolitan Electricity Authority (MEA) is a state enterprise wholly owned by the Kingdom of Thailand. It was established in July 1958 under the Metropolitan Electricity Authority Act. MEA is responsible for the distribution of electricity in the Bangkok metropolis and the adjoining provinces of Nonthaburi and Samut Prakan. Its current service area covers about 3,200 square kilometers with a population of about 7.3 million people. MEA supplies about 1.8 million industrial, commercial and domestic consumers. Although originally MEA also generated electricity, its power generation function was transferred in September 1961 to what is now the Electricity Generating Authority of Thailand (EGAT), which now supplies bulk power to MEA. A. INSTITUTIONAL ANALYSIS Organization and Management 2.2 MEA is accountable to the Government through the Ministry of Interior. Policy control is exercised through a Cabinet-approved Board of Directors composed of 14 members, including the Permanent Secretary of Interior as Chairman and the Governor of MEA in an ex-officio capacity. The Board, which meets monthly, operates with limited autonomy in a regulated environment: government approvals and clearances are required on matters such as the investment program, annual capital budget, borrowing, pricing, organizational structure, appointment of senior staff, and major procurement decisions. 2.3 The original organization structure of MEA was based on a functional design, with clear division of responsibilities and authority and a clear chain of command running from top to bottom. Over the years, the organization structure (Chart 1) has evolved and developed in response to continuing changes in MEA's external and internal environments. The growth in the volume of electricity sales, increased number of customers and changes in office systems have given rise to the establishment of new districts, the development of additional administrative and control procedures in Head Office departments, and increases in staffing in most units of the organization. MEA's desire to create new promotional positions to solve staff morale, retain key staff, reward superior performance and avoid loss of successful staff to the private sector also led to new sections, new divisions and even new departments. As a result, MEA's organizational structure, which prior to October 1, 1996 had 26 functional departments at Head Office and more than 240 individual sections, had become fragmented and complex. 2.4 Since inception, MEA has operated in close proximity to the Government and its departments. As a result, MEA has developed a bureaucratic culture. Creativity, risk taking, and professional and personal growth, particularly amongst younger professionals, are discouraged, the responsibility for achievement of results is diffused and managers experience little sense of personal accountability. The introduction of a business culture in all of its organizational levels is necessary in order for MEA to move from an activity-oriented to a result-oriented management. A consultant study (in association with Bank's Loan 3598-TH) has recommended the development of a new business culture in which: (a) risk is balanced against cost; (b) managers at
 I1 all levels are involved and participate fully in the overall management process; and (c) management and staff are committed to the effective achievement of MEA objectives. With the increasingly complex tasks that MEA would be facing in: (a) evolving an efficient distribution network in a difficult environment; (b) improving the safety, reliability and environmental acceptability of its operations; and (c) positioning itself towards achieving an excellent state enterprise status with subsequent commercialization and corporatization, it is imperative that MEA takes urgent steps to introduce a business culture into its organization and operate as a commercial company. MEA management has embraced the need for a change in its business culture and is now engaged in organizational restructuring to fall in line with modern management practice. In this effort, it would need substantial technical assistance and advice. Staffing and Resource Management 2.5 MEA's management and staff are professional and well-qualified. The average age of the staff is 41 years old. About a third of the staff have received some form of higher education.  3. THE PROJECT A. PROJECT OBJECTIVES, PERFORMANCE MONITORING AND PROJECT DESCRIPTION 3.1 Objectives. The main objectives of the proposed project are to: (a) improve the reliability of the distribution system and contain losses at current levels, while meeting the projected rapid increase in electricity demand; (b) assist in the organizational restructuring of MEA leading to its commercialization and corporatization; and (c) introduce demand-side management capabilities in MEA's organization thus deepening the DSM focus in the country's most rapidly growing area. 3.2 Performance Monitoring.  5. PROJECT JUSTIFICATION A. JUSTIFICATION 5.1 Benefits. The continuing increase in electricity demand in the metropolitan Bangkok area has made it imperative for MEA to install new substations, construct new feeder outlets and undertake system improvements to deliver power to consumers while maintaining an acceptable quality of power supply (i.e. adequate levels of circuit loading, operational reliability and losses). The project forms an important part of MEA' s least-cost expansion program. Its implementation would help ensure the country's continued economic growth by facilitating the development of its principal administrative, commercial and industrial center of Bangkok. Investments by MEA in improving its system reliability, which has been of concern to the Government in recent times, would translate into substantial economic benefits, especially to industrial and commercial consumers. The institutional restructuring of MEA would contribute to the efficiency of its operations and facilitate its commercialization and corporatization. The building up of DSM capabilities within MEA would enable it to actively engage in Thailand's DSM program (hitherto exclusively handled by EGAT), and lead to enhanced energy savings. 5.2 Least-Cost Planning. MEA has developed a master plan for supplying Bangkok, which establishes the technical characteristics of supply from EGAT and distribution within the city. Within the framework of this plan, MEA performs detailed least-cost analysis to ensure a cost effective expansion of its distribution system to meet the demand growth. It uses: (a) the "Simulation-Based Load Forecasting" computer program for small area load forecast; (b) the "SUBSITF' computer program for determining the optimum size, location and timing of substations; and (c) the "Constrained Multi Feeder" computer program for optimizing the sub- transmission system. These programs take into consideration alternative distribution developments and assist in establishing the least-cost expansion. 5.3 ERR Evaluation Methodology. The proposed project consists of a number of dispersed components which form an integral part of MEA's total investment program, covering its entire franchise area. Most major transmission and distribution investments in the MEA area are interrelated, and yield joint benefits of loss control, reliability improvement and incremental supply to consumers. For this reason, the MEA investment program for 1997-2001 was evaluated as a whole, rather than attempting to isolate individual components artificially. The following assumptions support the economic analysis: (a) the analysis is done in end- 1995 price levels; (b) the cost streams comprise: (i) capital investments in the system during 1997-2001, exclusive of duties and taxes, interest during construction and capital contributions from the consumers; and (ii) operation, maintenance and administrative costs of the system expansion. No allowance is made for shadow exchange rate because this value is set by the market. Also, it is considered that wages reflect the opportunity cost of labor; therefore, no shadow values are applied;
 35 (c) the cost of incremental energy purchased from EGAT is evaluated in terms of long-run marginal cost of supply of Baht 1.45/kWh (as established by consultant's studies updated by NEPO); (d) the incremental operation, maintenance and administrative costs are evaluated at 2.5% of the incremental capital costs, based on MEA's experience; (e) for evaluating the economic benefit arising from the incremental sales of electricity, the appropriate parameter is the consumer's willingness-to-pay (WTP). The WTP in metropolitan Bangkok area is substantially higher than the electricity tariff However, for the purpose of this analysis, the average tariff of Baht 2.02/kWh (the lower bound of WTP) realized in 1995 is used as a proxy for evaluating benefits from incremental sales. This WTP value is assumed to remain constant in real terms throughout the project life of 25 years; (f) as all incremental sales in the initial years cannot be attributed to the incremental investments, the incremental electricity sales over the investment period are conservatively assumed as: (i) 60% of the forecast incremental sales in 1997; (ii) 80% of the forecast incremental sales in 1998; and (iii) 100% of the forecast incremental sales from 1999 to 2001, remaining constant thereafter; (g) the losses are assumed to be maintained at the current level of 4.7% which is considered to be near optimum for MEA's system; and (h) the system reliability is assumed to increase progressively to yield an "unsupplied energy" saving (as evaluated in detail by MEA) rising from 0.8 Gwh in 1997 to 8.0 Gwh in 2002. The benefit due to savings in "unsupplied energy" is valued at Baht 59/kWh based on a recent study done by consultants. 5.4 On the basis of the above assumptions, the Economic Rate of Return (ERR) of MEA's investment program is computed at 20.4% (Annex 17). This value is considered to be conservative in the absence of quantification of consumer surplus and the environmental/safety benefits of MEA's program, which includes costly conversion to underground systems in several areas of Bangkok. The ERR is tested for variations of two types of parameters: (i) those directly related to specific project risks, such as increase in capital costs, and reduction in sales (caused by implementation delays or a slow demand growth); and (ii) basic power prices and variables difficult to quantify, such as the cost of unsupplied energy (see Table 5.1). 5.5 The ERR of MEA's investment program is relatively insensitive to the program's capital cost and the quantum of electricity sales. The ERR also remains robust at 18.9% when the benefit due to saving in "unsupplied energy" is not evaluated. The ERR is quite sensitive to the cost of energy and to the WTP, being dependent on the difference between two parameters that have close values.

In 1992, the Government approved legislation establishing the Energy Conservation Promotion Act, which increased the commitment and resources necessary to implement a comprehensive energy efficiency program. The Act: (a) formalized the responsibilities of the Department of Energy Development and Promotion (DEDP) as the IEVD Government agency for energy conservation; (b) gave DEDP the authority to issue voluntary building energy codes and appliance efficiency standards; (c) identified a class of large energy users as '"ontrolled facilities" and required that they hire energy managers, conduct energy studies and develop energy conservation plans; and (d) established the Energy Conservation Promotion Fund (ECF), financed largely through taxes on refinery products. 2. In addition, by the approval of a motion put forward by the National Energy Policy Office (NEPO), the Thai Cabinet gave EGAT the legal mandate and authority to pursue DSM programs, targeting appliances in six categories that significantly contribute to Thailand's electricity demand growth - lighting measures, air conditioners, refrigerators, freezers, ballasts and motors. In December 1992, the Demand-Side Management Office (DSMO) was created within EGAT to take charge in the design, implementation and evaluation of DSM programs. The distribution utilities, MEA and the Provincial Electricity Authority (PEA), are also charged to cooperate with EGAT in DSM implementation in their respective service territories. The DSM Sub-Committee (DSMSC) was established to oversee the progress of DSM implementation. 3. In recognition of the unique potential of the Thai DSM effort to serve as a model for energy conservation and greenhouse gas emission reduction efforts in other countries, the World Bank under the auspices of the Global Environment Facility (GEF) has supported the Promotion of Electricity Energy Efficiency Project since 1993. The project has two main objectives: (a) to build sufficient institutional capability in the Thai electric power sector and the energy-related private sector to deliver cost-effective energy services throughout the economy; and (b) to pursue policies and actions that would IEVD to the development, manufacture and adoption of energy-efficient equipment and processes within the country. 4. The GEF project is substantially serving these objectives. With respect to the first objective of building institutional capability, the GEF project has spearheaded the creation of the DSMO at EGAT with 120 trained staff and successfully utilized the Thai Industrial Standard Institute (TISI) for testing the energy efficiency of various appliances. With respect to the second objective of pursuing policies and actions, the GEF project has begun implementation of several key DSM programs such as the high- efficiency fluorescent tube, air conditioner, refrigerator, compact fluorescent lamp, green building and motor programs. The DSMO estimated that, as of January 1997, these measures have achieved energy savings of 1,009 gigawatt-hours (GWh) per year, reduced the peak demand by 136 megawatts (MW) and led to a 753,000 ton reduction in carbon dioxide (C02) emissions per year by avoiding energy generation. 5. However, DSM implementation in Thailand has, until now, been shouldered almost exclusively by the DSMO in EGAT. There has been little involvement to date in DSM development and

 102 Annex 16 Page 1 of 2 THAILAND Metropolitan Distribution Reinforcement Project New Bulk's Supply Tariff Proposed Mechanism for New Bulk Supply Tariff The current approach to setting the BST has been determined to have three significant drawbacks. Firstly, by mixing the BST and the cross subsidy mechanism, neither MIEA nor PEA face, at the margin, an accurate signal of the true cost of generation and transmission in their respective regions. Secondly, this condition makes it very difficult to identify the scale of the current financial transfer from MEA to PEA and hence, to identify either the underlying financial position of either utility, or the true cost to MEA consumers of the uniform national tariff policy. Lastly, the current approach risks weakening the efficiency incentives on PEA and MEA, the risk being that both MEA and PEA may come to believe that additional costs which it incurs will be compensated by a futher reduction in its BST and corresponding increase in the BST paid by the other. Clearly, a new mechanism is needed to deal with these drawbacks that would: (a) be consistent with the overall approach to the Government's policy on tariff determination; (b) enable the costs of the cross subsidy to be clearly transparent, identifiable and separable from the BST; (c) leave all utilities with strong incentives to improve efficiency and reduce costs; and (d) enable the BST to give both MEA and PEA an accurate signal of the true costs of generation and transmission in their respective regions. A new mechanism, prepared by consultants of the BST study, proposed the following changes: (a) EGAT would charge a common BST to PEA and MEA which would reflect accurately the bulk cost of energy and capacity to both utilities; (b) the cross subsidy would occur through separate financial transfer from MBA and EGAT to PEA called the Uniform Tariff Compensation Payment (UTCP); (c) the UTCPs would not be a fund, would always have a zero balance, and would be paid into and received from a single bank account; and (d) the size of the UTCP will be determined by the regulator as part of the periodic tariff review for each of the subsequent five years before the next review. Proposed New Tariff Determination and Setting Process Under the proposed system, BST and tariff levels would be determined using the allowed revenue approach arrived at through six consecutive steps. Step 1 would determine the base value of allowed revenue (Base Allowed Revenue) for generation, transmission, distribution and retail activities in each year during the review period, based on forecast values for demand, controllable and uncontrollable costs carried out by EGAT, MBA and PEA. Step 2, which would also be carried out during tariff review, would derive the level of tariffs (Base Tariffs) for both BST and final retail customers, required to recover the Base Allowed Revenue determined in Step 1, assuming forecast demand in each year. Step 3, carried out at the end of the first year following the tariff review, would determine the Average Tariff Revenue recovered in the first year, by multiplying the Base Tariffs determined in Step 2, by total actual demand for that year. Step 4, also undertaken at the end of the first year, would calculate the value of revenue (Revised Allowed Revenue) which would have been allowed in the first year if the uncontrollable costs and demand had been correctly forecast when Base Allowed Revenue was determined in Step 1. Step
 103 Annex 16 Page 2 of 2 5 would determine the difference (Revenue Correction) between the Average Tariff Revenue calculated in Step 3 and the Revised Allowed Revenue calculated in Step 4. Finally, Step 6 would adjust the Base Tariffs for Year 2 of the review period taking into account the Revenue Correction required in respect of Year 1, expressed as a constant percentage increase to the Base Tariff Level. An illustration of the proposed process in given in page 3 of this annex. The Base Allowed Revenue for generation, transmission, distribution and retail acitivities would be determined by reviewing operating and investment costs of each utility, comparing them against regional benchmarks, and adjusting these costs by a 4% efficiency improvement factor to ensure that costs are aligned with acceptable regional standards. Then using EGAT, MEA and PEA financial models, the total revenue would be calculated to meet the required financial criteria. The financial performance criteria is critical in determining the revenue which each utility would be allowed and takes into consideration the sufficiency of revenues to guarantee the utilities' financial health, efficiency incentives, and simplicity of administration. Hence, the following financial criteria would be used in the calculation: (a) a minimum SFR of 25%; (b) a 15% maximum ratio of short and medium term debt to total debt; (c) a 1.5x minimum debt coverage ratio; (d) a 1.5x maximum debt to equity ratio; and (e) a 2.Ox minimum interest cover ratio. On the basis of initial calculations, the utilities should be able to meet on average all investment and operating costs over the period between reviews, however, it may not meet these performance criteria in each year of the review period since the annual revenue requirements in each year are smoothed to give a Base Allowed Revenue profile for each utility. While the specific financial criteria are consistent with the Bank covenants under the respective Loan Agreements, Bank covenants, however, are drafted on the basis of results of annual performance. It is therefore likely that the utilities would either re-negotiate the relevant loan covenants to recognize that criteria may not be met on an annual basis or adjust the values for the performance criteria used to define annual revenue requirements to ensure that the smoothed profile for Base Allowed Revenue allows the utilities to meet or exceed the covenanted criteria in each year of the review period. Uniform Tariff Compensation Payment The UTCP under the new BST is the proposed mechanism designed to preserve the national uniform tariff while providing comparable financial criteria for MEA and PEA and be cost reflective signals to each utility through the BST. For each utility, the Base UTCP is the difference between the Base Allowed Revenue for that utility and the revenue received from national uniform cross-subsidized tariffs. After deriving the actual UTCP for each utility, payments or receipts are made through a UTCP account. The UTCP mechanism is expected to be operated without further intervention from NEPO apart for its role in setting the Base UTCP and monitoring the application of adjustment formulae.

doc.abstracts: The main objectives of the Metropolitan Distribution Reinforcement Project are to: (i) improve the reliability of the distribution system and contain losses at current levels, while meeting the projected rapid increase in electricity demand; (ii) assist in the organization restructuring of the Metropolitan Electricity Authority (MEA) leading to its commercialization and corporatization; and (iii) introduce demand-side management (DSM) capabilities in MEA's organization thus deepening the DSM focus in the country's most rapidly growing area. The components of the project are the following: 1) investment component including transmission and distribution substation system; transmission line systems; and distribution system; 2) policy component providing for a major restructuring of MEA's organization; and 3) institutional development component comprising: (i) setting up of an Appliance Testing Laboratory; (ii) introduction of a system-wide Load Research program; (iii) implementation of a load control program; (iv) establishment of an Energy Service Company; and (v) technical assistance.
